transcript.transcript: And ten, and we are here for an oral interview with Professor James Buchanan. My name is Nona Martin, and Bob Vay is behind the camera, and we will be conducting an oral history interview on behalf of George Mason Oral History Program. Our interview is taking place in the Buchanan House on the Fairfax campus of George Mason. Thank you so much, Doctor Buchanan, for this interview. For the first question, it's a relatively easy one. What made you decide to come to George Mason? Well, that's quite a long story. I have always felt that you don't really come to places. You really leave places. And in a sense, we came to George Mason because things down at Virginia Tech for us got somewhat unfavorable. And we had good entrepreneurship here to make it very attractive for us to come up here. We moved our whole staff, faculty and staff and endowment. We moved from Virginia Tech to George Mason in 1983, and we had had some problems down there about the direction of the economics program down there. We had an ongoing, good, viable graduate program going, but then we had a chairman who came in and wanted to change the direction. He wanted to make the program much more mathematical, much more formal than we had been successful with down there. And as a result, things just became somewhat intolerable. And we were kind of vulnerable to good entrepreneurship on the part of some alternative. And we had several other options, possibilities. But then I always liked the state of Virginia, and I was attracted to the possibilities of setting up a new program up here. The graduate program in economics was brand new, and we had a good opportunity to shape it up a little bit and excellent entrepreneurship on the part of Karen Vaughan, who was chairman of the department at that time up here, and also Wade Gilley, who was the academic vice president at that time, and then George Johnson, who was president. They all were very helpful in providing the spirit of giving us the idea that it would be a very good idea to come up here at this opportunity for this new place, a new university, and really getting off the ground. And so that was the sort of origins of the of the whole thing. And how many people did you bring with you? I think there were seven faculty people plus a couple of staff people. Okay. Yeah. Very good. And what was the economics department like when you arrived? Uh, well, it had um, um, sort of the main accomplishment of the economics department was that it had got approved already, the PhD program through the Council of Higher Education. It had got that approved, and they were beginning to set it up. It had some good people in the department, but they weren't as as well known as some of us were. Uh, they had some people who were doing some very effective work and beginning to get a program of an Austrian slant to the program, um, and a sort of beginning to establish a name for George Mason within limits. And we, of course, doubled, at least doubled or tripled the size of the whole operation when we came up here. Okay. While you were up here, um, did the center for the Study of Public Choice change any. Did it become a kind of different organization? Not really. Not as a result of the change. It in a way it did. In a way it did in the sense that down at Virginia Tech, we had an absolutely perfect setting for our research center. We had the former president's house, which is now again the president's house down there. But it was a facility all independent, but yet close to everything. And geographically, it was a wonderful spot. Everybody had offices there and so forth and so on. And then when we left down there and moved up here, I said there were seven faculty, I think that came, but there were about three that were would be considered public choice, people who did not come with us. So it was not quite as as viable as as it had been. So Um, there were at least three, I think, of that stayed down there. Um, and then we never have had never did have the as nice a geographical setting up here as we did down there, especially when we went into Corolla Hall, which was not very. It's all right as an academic building, but it's not a not like we had down there more or less. And geography matters. Matters a great deal. I found that out. How how did that manifest itself, the difference in geography. Well, just the fact that we had an independent, large building with perfectly good offices, seminar room and so forth and so on that, and people left their doors open. They wandered in and out and they could get discussions going. And it was a very active intellectual environment that we never quite accomplished here. to some extent we did, but never did quite get it going in the same way we did down there. Okay. Yeah. Was that because some people were in a different area than others or just it just didn't work? Well, I think the people who were in public choice were all in one building up here. The rest of the department was over in another building. And, uh, I think it I don't know, maybe it was the timing and lots of other reasons. I don't know, but it's difficult to know. Would you talk about some of your former colleagues here? You mentioned Karen Vaughan already. Yeah. What was your relationship like with her? Well, I had a very good relationship with Karen. She was an excellent chairman of the department, and she was really responsible for building up that department and that whole program. And she was a good, solid economist, and she was the one who was the central motivator for that emphasis on the Austrian market process type of study. There were 2 or 3 other people that were involved with her pretty early on, but she was the one who sort of was dominant in that particular program. Okay. Um, I have a couple more people. Um, Gordon Tullock. Yeah. Yeah. Well, Gordon, of course, came with us from with me, and he's where he worked with me for 3 or 4 decades of very active collaboration on research. And we, of course, wrote that book, The Calculus of Consent in 1962, published in 62, which was became a kind of a seminal work in public choice and is still selling well. As a matter of fact, it became kind of a classic. And Gordon and I were spending lots and lots of time discussing joint interests, and we published other things after that. But gradually our work departed somewhat. My emphasis shifted from his emphasis, and of course, when he came back after he left and went to Arizona for ten years and came back, he was located at the law school rather than out here. So that made it more difficult to do any joint work. Again. Geography, huh? Again. Geography. Yeah. And what about Walter Williams? Well, I had known Walter from UCLA days. I had spent a year and a half at UCLA in 69, 68, 69. Um, and Walter, I think, was an advanced graduate student at that time. I think he took my course. He was mainly influenced by Armen Alchian, but he was around. I remember him from those days, uh, and I kept in touch with him after that. And then, uh, I don't think I had much direct contact with him here in terms of joint enterprises. But on the other hand, I knew he was around. Yeah. And your fellow Nobel Prize winner, Vernon Smith. Did you guys have any interaction? Well, he didn't come until after I was officially retired, so I knew I had known Vernon for years and years. But even when he was at Purdue and then at Arizona and then when he was starting up, a lot of that experimental stuff. But and I had a former student who worked very closely with him, Charles Plott, but who was at Caltech, but, uh, The Vernon was not here actively while I was still active. I had more or less retired by the time he came here. And I read that you had a student who also became a colleague. Doctor. Boettke. Peter. Boettke. Peter. Boettke. Yeah. He, uh. He was a student after I came here. He was a graduate student at George Mason and a very good student and very became very active after he came back on the faculty here and is now one of the leading, you know, members of the school. It was a good write up on him in the Wall Street Journal not a month or two ago. I have that clipping in my research. I saw that you went to Middle Tennessee State Teachers College. Yeah. So did you always want to be a teacher? No no no no no no, not at all. Uh, um, the very simple reason for the Middle Tennessee State Teachers College. My family had groomed me to go to Vanderbilt University, which was in Nashville, 30 miles from home. Um, but by the time I got through high school ready to go to university, there was no way I could go to Vanderbilt because that was a costly place. Murfreesboro, Middle Tennessee was only nine miles down the road, and I could stay at home and milk cows and do the work every day and get a little money and catch a ride in. And so it was local. It was strictly the only local possibility I could afford, and that's the reason I went there. Uh, as far as teaching goes, it was of course, you had to take a lot of boring courses in education by the requirements. Uh, but the and you had to do practice teaching. And so my practice teaching was teaching high school algebra. And I learned from that one episode that I was teaching was never going to be a problem. I suppose I have kind of an authoritarian personality or something, because I had never any problem with discipline or anything else. I mean, students always paid attention to me, in other words. So in that sense, I was a natural teacher, but I didn't have the urge to teach as such. You know. Did that ever change? Like maybe when you got graduate students or was teaching something not so important? Well, there was a sort of a seismic shift in my way. I did things when I moved to after I'd spent what might be called journeyman years at the University of Tennessee and at Florida State, where I was teaching, you know, regular teaching, more or less undergraduates and graduates. When I shifted to the University of Virginia in 1956, I started teaching a graduate course in public finance, welfare economics, public finance, and I shifted my way of teaching because I always had a small group, and I was very active in my own interest at that time, working on some material and, uh, which became a lot of public choice later. But, um, I found that the way to teach that course was to get the students involved with me working on what I was working on, so they would write papers, little short papers, and I would grade them. And we it was really an interactive teaching experience that was very successful, and it was well known. And I turned out a lot of really top notch people, um, as a result of that. So from that day on, my teaching was quite different from what it had been up until then. Okay, there was nothing no rote teaching after that. No. No teaching. What was down in the book or in, you know, that sort of thing. It was all original stuff, you know. Um, has can you point to someone who's had an influence on how you teach, or is it something that you just developed along the way? Uh, well, there there is. I think I can point to some I mentioned some of this in my autobiography. Um. There are two types of teachers, so to speak, that I had in graduate school. Uh, and one of them did influence me a lot, I think. Um, there's the teacher who feels like he needs to put the student down. That is to make the student feel very humble, and therefore he becomes very negative toward that student, makes that student embarrass, tries his best to break the confidence of that student. Jacob Viner was famous for that at the University of Chicago, and I had the honors course in international economics. That was not the one I emulated. I wanted to be something else. And another man, T.W. Schultz, who was chairman of the department up there and who later got the Nobel Prize, was an agricultural economist. Um, he really had a big influence on me in the following way he would to a graduate class, he would say somebody would raise a kind of a stupid question. And Schultz would always say, well, Mr. Jones, there may be something in what you're saying. And he would always lead the student to think that there was something there. It was it was almost the opposite of Viner's approach. Rather than beating down the student, Schultz would take a stupid student and make him think he was making a contribution. So and I adopted essentially that. But whether it was direct from Schultz or whether it was just my general characteristic, I'm not sure. Okay. Um, when you were here, do you have any recollection, recall, recollection of the way Mason students, um, compared to the others that you taught in other universities? Not really. Because, you see, I didn't ever teach. I don't think I ever taught an undergraduate course here. What about the graduate students here? As I say, it was a new program, and we were beginning to get a mixture of some good students and some bad ones and some mediocre ones. And it was kind of getting the program off the ground, so to speak. So it's difficult to make a comparison. There certainly weren't as good as the University of Virginia, but as Virginia Tech when I was there, compared to George Mason, We had some students that would do well, others not so well. Um, of your many students over the years, are there any that stand out in your memory? Students who are here. Who were here? Mason. Students. Well, you mentioned Peter Bethke. Okay. Uh. I'm not sure I have students who come to see me and say they took my course, and I know I've forgotten who they are. Uh, David Kreutzer, who was at James Madison, who works part time for heritage. I see him on television every now and then as a commentator. Okay. Um, what did you learn from your teacher, Frank Knight at UChicago? Everything. Everything. Everything. Now, what I learned from Frank Knight was basically more of an attitude than a than a set of principles or anything. The thing I learned, and I think everybody who took Knight night. Learned from night was that everything's up for grabs intellectually. You challenge everything. You take nothing on, on authority. You don't accept anything, and you question it and work it out to your own. You puzzle it out. This sort of challenge to conventional wisdom in all areas, in all dimensions. That's the key lesson that Frank and I taught you. Okay. Why did you choose economics. Purely by accident? Okay. Uh, the again, I go through this story in my autobiography. Um, when I graduated from college from Middle Tennessee State Teacher's College, it was at that time, uh, now, of course, it's Middle Tennessee University. They've all gone through that change. But when I graduated, I had three employment options. This was in the spring of 1940. I could teach school. I had all the credentials I could teach high school in my home county at $65 a month. I could go to work in Nashville, Tennessee, at a bank, at the Commerce Union Bank, at, I think, $80 a month. And I got a fellowship from the University of Tennessee in economics at $50 a month. Well, obviously, the fellowship dominated the other options because I could get room and board, full room and board for $26 a month. And so I had a little leftover. And so obviously the fellowship dominated. But I had three majors in undergraduate. I had a major in social sciences. They didn't have economics as a single major, and I had a major in English literature, and I had major in mathematics. And I've always said I could have easily have been a literary critic had there been a fellowship aVaylable in literature. Or I could have been a mathematician. Had there been a fellowship aVaylable there. So I mean, economics, not because I wanted to save the world. A lot of my peers economics. About the time I did, they went in because they had possibilities. Economics was going to help the world. Mine was just strictly because I that was where the fellowship was. Already employing economic thinking. Yeah. Yeah. Um, I've read a couple of places where you've been called a maverick. Is that a correct description of you or your work? Um, well, I know what they mean when they say that, uh, when I have never been interested in sort of toeing the line, so to speak, staying with the herd. I've always been, uh, moving out in different dimensions, trying to be a little different, at least since I've been trying to be productive again, goes back to Frank Knight's influence about you. You challenge everything. You question everything. You don't. So my work has never been embroidering around the edges of the conventions. That is to Orthodoxy. I've always challenged the orthodoxy and tried to get as deep a challenge as I could. I wrote my book on public debt early on, which was a complete challenge to the orthodoxy, and I guess that's where they get that maverick notion. And of course, Tulloch and I in our book were challenging the orthodoxy and political science in a big way. And so as we went into, I suppose, in that sense being, if you think of a maverick as being someone who's outside the main herd mainstream, so to speak, that fits. Okay. If you were to recommend just one piece of writing, it can be a book or an article that you wrote to someone, who would it be? Which one? Well, it would depend on the purpose. Depending on what you'd want to want to use it for. Uh. If you. If, I suppose if you want to slant on the public choice part, uh, I wrote a piece called Politics Without Romance, uh, which was a summary of sort of this public choice approach or thrust. I gave that as an inaugural lecture at the Institute for Higher Studies in Vienna. Uh, one time about 1985, I guess. So long in there or maybe earlier. But, uh, if you want other, you know, more more of a philosophical views or something else or or personal or. Okay. Thank you. Would you say you've already told me that Frank Knight had an influence on your attitude and the way you challenged orthodoxy? Are there other scholars that have had large influence on your research? Maybe on the questions you ask. Let me think on that a little bit. Uh. Well. In in the expanded version of my autobiography, I put in one chapter, uh, of ten people who have been important in my thinking. Uh, and that was chapter was in response, really to a Danish journal who wrote around to different people and said, well, I want you to write. They asked me to write a little blurb on ten people who have influenced me, and write one page on each one. And so I wrote that up, and then I used that as a chapter in this expanded version when a chapter in this book. But so I guess you could go in that sense, I start out with Frank Knight, of course, and then go back to history. Adam Smith, of course, influences all economists in a very important way. And then the one who influenced me, and I'm associated with more directly as Newt Vesell, who was a great Swedish economist writing around the turn of the of the last century. He. Go. I think was born in 1851, died in 1926. But he was the one who really got me thinking on these rules and constitutions and this sort of thing. And I translated his book in his German dissertation into English, and I was excited about him. He had a big influence on me. But those are the dead economists, the ones who were living influences. Um, uh, I think Kenneth Arrow influenced me a lot because I was attacking him, so to speak. He was a good, good target for my criticism of the whole social welfare function, welfare economics thrusts. And I was criticizing that. So arrow became kind of a target in a more positive sense. Um, I think the Von Neumann-morgenstern theory of games had a huge influence on on economics generally, and certainly on my thinking, not so much when it came out, but when later, as it kind of was absorbed into the thinking that had a big influence. The theory of games had a big influence. John Rawls had a big influence who was a theory of justice. Harvard philosopher. I also read that you have a habit of being an early riser. Is that still true? Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah. Always. I never was able to work at night. I always worked early in the day. I guess that's a farm background. Makes that true. Uh, and to this day, I get up very early, and, uh, whatever little work I do, I do in the mornings, basically. So how do you spend your days? Most days. These days? Well, these days I spend most of my time in Blacksburg. I have this, uh, spread down there. I call it a farm if you want to. I don't do any active farming, but I let people run cattle on it and get hay from it. And it's mostly mountain land, but I have a lot of spread. I've got a lot of acreage. In other words, it's mostly just around. I have about a square mile, actually, of acreage, uh, several houses on it that I let other people live in. But basically, uh, my day is pretty well. Um, as I say, I work a little in the morning. I still, I find it very. Even though I'm 91, I still find life interesting. Only if I can be developing an idea I need to have targets for, like, just. I just finished a paper and I've got another paper coming on, and I need to have targets and have like, I'm going to give another paper in Frankfurt, Germany in November, and I need to have just finished giving a seminar last week in down at Virginia Tech. So I need to have. That's what keeps me driving. I don't like retirement as sitting in the rocking chair looking at the world. It's got to be more than just looking at the world. I think that would be a miserable existence. So what questions are you pondering these days? Well, I have this last paper, the one that I finished and gave a seminar on, uh, had to do with trying to understand why so many economists. Took this view that the market would always work, and it allowed this crisis to happen when they should have understood that the market will only work if you have the right rules. It goes back to my emphasis on rules. And obviously the market can't set its own rules. You won't get to own a lot of these financial instruments and these new gimmicks and gadgets that came up in the financial sector wouldn't should never have been accepted as sort of the fact that they came up through a market meant that they were good rules. Uh, economists kind of neglected that. And that's my whole emphasis on that now, is trying to understand a little more about why they made those mistakes, why they did that. And I think I've got some, some, some key answers. And I'm working with my colleague here, Yang Yun, uh, to develop that a little bit, a little bit more, uh, which ultimately has to do with, with what is the and it goes back to Adam Smith. Really? What, uh, what are the sets of laws and institutions within which markets work? My, my view of the market is the market will work, but it'll only work if it's constrained properly by institutions and those rules and institutions. institution, they have to be chosen in another way from the fact that they emerge in a marketplace. So that's sort of what I'm working on. Okay. Well, that is the end of the questions. Very good, very good. Is there anything you would like to add about your time here at Mason, about your colleagues here at Mason? No, I think it's a very active place. George Mason is a very active place. And you add all them up. You have some extremely good people here. Uh, it's a good place and very active. It's always encouraged. The spirit of entrepreneurship. It is really good in that sense. Programs and so forth. And they have a very good graduate program in terms of students. And that I do think it lacks, uh, it lacks some coherence. That is, everybody is sort of riding off in their own directions, I think. I think it needs it needs a focus. It needs somebody to sit in and sort of guide the thing. Maybe it's past that stage, I don't know. Is this multidirectional thing a new phenomenon or was it more focused before? Do you think? Well, I guess I compare it with our situation down at Virginia Tech when we were at the peak of our situation there in the early 70s. Uh, it may be inevitable that you get this at a large place as it develops. Certainly at the big universities, you get that. I mean, they don't have a coherent unit program somehow or another. You sort of an ideal would be to have a program that's, uh, more coherent, that different people would be spending more time talking to each other, rather than each of them trying to maximize their own little world, you know, out there. Okay. Thank you very. Much. Yeah, I appreciate that.

lines.line: # Decision to Move to George Mason

> The speaker explains that the decision to move to George Mason was influenced by unfavorable conditions at Virginia Tech. The change in leadership and direction in the economics program at Virginia Tech led to a search for better opportunities, which George Mason provided. The entire staff, faculty, and endowment were moved in 1983, attracted by the entrepreneurship and the opportunity to shape a new graduate program in economics.

metadata.title: Decision to Move to George Mason
metadata.synopsis: The speaker explains that the decision to move to George Mason was influenced by unfavorable conditions at Virginia Tech. The change in leadership and direction in the economics program at Virginia Tech led to a search for better opportunities, which George Mason provided. The entire staff, faculty, and endowment were moved in 1983, attracted by the entrepreneurship and the opportunity to shape a new graduate program in economics.

lines.line: # Transition and Initial Setup at George Mason

> Upon arriving at George Mason, the speaker brought seven faculty members and a couple of staff people. The economics department was in its early stages, having just gotten approval for a PhD program. The speaker discusses the transition of the Center for the Study of Public Choice from Virginia Tech to George Mason, noting the differences in the geographical setting and its impact on the intellectual environment.

metadata.title: Transition and Initial Setup at George Mason
metadata.synopsis: Upon arriving at George Mason, the speaker brought seven faculty members and a couple of staff people. The economics department was in its early stages, having just gotten approval for a PhD program. The speaker discusses the transition of the Center for the Study of Public Choice from Virginia Tech to George Mason, noting the differences in the geographical setting and its impact on the intellectual environment.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses his relationships with several colleagues at George Mason, including Karen Vaughan, Gordon Tullock, Walter Williams, and Vernon Smith. He highlights their contributions to the department and their influence on the academic environment. The speaker also mentions his interactions with Peter Boettke, a former student who became a colleague.

metadata.title: Influential Colleagues at George Mason
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses his relationships with several colleagues at George Mason, including Karen Vaughan, Gordon Tullock, Walter Williams, and Vernon Smith. He highlights their contributions to the department and their influence on the academic environment. The speaker also mentions his interactions with Peter Boettke, a former student who became a colleague.

lines.line: > The speaker reflects on his teaching career, noting that he did not initially aspire to be a teacher. His teaching philosophy was significantly influenced by his experiences and the methods of his mentors, particularly at the University of Virginia. He emphasizes the importance of engaging students in active research and discussions, which he found more effective than traditional teaching methods.

metadata.title: Teaching Philosophy and Influences
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on his teaching career, noting that he did not initially aspire to be a teacher. His teaching philosophy was significantly influenced by his experiences and the methods of his mentors, particularly at the University of Virginia. He emphasizes the importance of engaging students in active research and discussions, which he found more effective than traditional teaching methods.

lines.line: # Academic Influences and Personal Work Habits

> The speaker discusses the various scholars who have influenced his academic work, including Frank Knight, Adam Smith, and others. He also talks about his personal work habits, noting that he is an early riser and prefers to work in the mornings. His ongoing engagement with academic work and idea development is crucial to his sense of purpose and fulfillment.

metadata.title: Academic Influences and Personal Work Habits
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses the various scholars who have influenced his academic work, including Frank Knight, Adam Smith, and others. He also talks about his personal work habits, noting that he is an early riser and prefers to work in the mornings. His ongoing engagement with academic work and idea development is crucial to his sense of purpose and fulfillment.

lines.line: # Reflections on George Mason and Future Directions

> The speaker provides his thoughts on the current state of George Mason, praising its active environment and entrepreneurial spirit. However, he suggests that the university could benefit from more coherence and focus among its programs and faculty members. He reflects on the differences in academic focus compared to his time at Virginia Tech and the potential for improvement at George Mason.

The entire staff, faculty, and endowment were moved in 1983, attracted by the entrepreneurship and the opportunity to shape a new graduate program in economics.

> Upon arriving at George Mason, the speaker brought seven faculty members and a couple of staff people. His teaching philosophy was significantly influenced by his experiences and the methods of his mentors, particularly at the University of Virginia. He emphasizes the importance of engaging students in active research and discussions, which he found more effective than traditional teaching methods.
# Academic Influences and Personal Work Habits

> The speaker discusses the various scholars who have influenced his academic work, including Frank Knight, Adam Smith, and others. He also talks about his personal work habits, noting that he is an early riser and prefers to work in the mornings. His ongoing engagement with academic work and idea development is crucial to his sense of purpose and fulfillment.
# Reflections on George Mason and Future Directions

> The speaker provides his thoughts on the current state of George Mason, praising its active environment and entrepreneurial spirit. However, he suggests that the university could benefit from more coherence and focus among its programs and faculty members. He reflects on the differences in academic focus compared to his time at Virginia Tech and the potential for improvement at George Mason.
